claims.claim: TRAPPIST-1 b has an atmosphere based on phase-curve evidence from JWST MIRI spectroscopy.

evidence.quote: The dataset provides meaningful evidence against a strictly airless interpretation for TRAPPIST-1 b
A pure no-atmosphere model cannot simultaneously match both phase amplitude and spectral band behavior.
Joint fit likelihood ratio (atmosphere vs no atmosphere): 7.4 ... Atmosphere-bearing models better explain combined data products

claims.caveat: Atmospheric composition and pressure remain uncertain enough that follow-up spectroscopy is essential, and retrieval assumptions affect quantitative posteriors.

claims.claim: Heat transport efficiency (epsilon) of 0.19 indicates non-zero day-night energy redistribution on TRAPPIST-1 b.

evidence.quote: Heat transport efficiency (epsilon): 0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14) ... Non-zero redistribution is favored
A non-zero redistribution parameter implies transport beyond an immediate bare-rock reradiation limit.

claims.caveat: The heat transport efficiency measurement has significant uncertainty (+0.23 / -0.14), and night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints.

claims.claim: CO2 spectral features at 15 um are detected, consistent with atmospheric absorption.

evidence.quote: 15 um CO2 spectral band depth estimate: 96 ppm ... Spectral structure is consistent with atmospheric absorption
Spectral structure near 15 um provides composition-sensitive evidence, especially for CO2-rich scenarios.

claims.caveat: Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features, and degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.

claims.claim: O2-rich atmosphere cases are not fully ruled out by current phase-curve data.

evidence.quote: O2-rich atmosphere cases are not fully ruled out by current data.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.

claims.caveat: The data quality is insufficient to distinguish between different atmospheric compositions, requiring broader wavelength coverage and repeated observations.

claims.claim: Joint constraints from phase curve and spectrum are stronger than either observable alone for detecting atmospheres.

evidence.quote: Joint constraints from phase curve and spectrum are stronger than either observable alone.
Thermal phase offsets and amplitudes probe day-night energy redistribution.

claims.caveat: This is a single-planet study and does not establish that this combined approach works for all M-dwarf rocky planets.
